content.raw:
currently libsdformat has two ways of loading files:

* `sdf::readFile(path)` fills an `sdf::SDF` object, which mainly checks for xml errors
* `sdf::Root::Load(path)` fills an `sdf::Root` dom object has more checks, like checking for sibling elements of the same type with the same name and if link inertias are physically valid

For the reference implementation of this proposal, I am only checking that sibling elements of any type must have unique names in `ign sdf --check`, not in any of the Load functions. I suppose we should define the error behavior for each API

Ideally, if a world \+ models are completely inlined, it would be nice if a world could “reach into” a model, and perhaps even vice versa. This is namely to support the welding workflow mentioned in the nesting proposal.

content.raw:
> we're saying `//collision/pose` can access frame names defined in the model scope, which is outside of it's most immediate scope

it's true that the model scope it outside of its most immediate scope as we usually define it (between siblings), but since this proposal isn't including `//link/frame` and we haven't defined implicit frames for any children of a link (collision, visual, etc), the collision has no implicit or explicit frames in its immediate scope. I think the idea is to let it go up in parent scopes recursively until the first defined frames are found and stop there

content.raw: What I am suggesting is that models and worlds define what I'm calling a "file" scope. So objects inside a model would not be able to access names outside of the model (even if the model is in the same file as the world). In your example,  `//collision/pose[@relative_to] = F`, the name `F` would refer to `//model/frame[@name] = F`. Maybe "file" scope may not be the right name, but it would be nice to differentiate the concept of general scopes, which align with xml parent child relationships, from the scoping rule that treats `//world` and `//model` as special scopes.

content.raw: Technically, links also have scopes since, for example, collision names in one link can match collision names in another link. However, we're saying `//collision/pose` can access frame names defined in the model scope, which is outside of it's most immediate scope. While I don't object to this, it does seem like a syntactic inconsistency not addressed by the scoping rules. One idea (and I think @{557057:f3a199b9-5784-4964-9644-6ef224bc7dc1} has mentioned it before) would be to differentiate world and model scopes as *file scopes* and state that all objects can refer to names in their immediate scopes as well as in parent scopes recursively as long as they are within the file scope.
content.html: Technically, links also have scopes since, for example, collision names in one link can match collision names in another link. However, we're saying //collision/pose can access frame names defined in the model scope, which is outside of it's most immediate scope. While I don't object to this, it does seem like a syntactic inconsistency not addressed by the scoping rules. One idea (and I think @Eric Cousineau has mentioned it before) would be to differentiate world and model scopes as file scopes and state that all objects can refer to names in their immediate scopes as well as in parent scopes recursively as long as they are within the file scope.

I've updated the parsing stages and copied a bit of the example from pull request #16 and discussed the `//link/frame` idea as an alternative considered.

I've targeted this at pull request #33 to avoid conflicts in the changes to the parsing stages.

This pull request is an alternative to pull request #16 and pull request #31.

Preview: http://sdformat.org/tutorials?tut=pose_frame_semantics_proposal&branch=frame_scoping_rules
